utterances: It's something that you might see outside a movie theater.
I love the program on the morning.
And by the way, it turns out that we may have maligned you at the beginning of this, Will.
We checked the transcript from yesterday morning, and you did not say that the capital of Ohio was Dayton...
...or that we were doing capital--state capitals.
That was me who said we were doing state capitals.
Yeah, my puzzle was Dover to Denver.
...we're taking back that lapel pin you did not get.
I have to turn in my dictionary now.
I have puzzles, but I don't have the answers, so I have...
Let's get a caller on the line.
It's kind of a logic puzzle.
Being an engineer, it's my favorite kind.
So you're outside a room and the door is closed and there's a lightbulb in the center of the room.
You can flick them any amount of times or any amount you'd like, but you can only open the door once.
How can you definitively tell which switch turns on the light?
You--OK, you have the three switches.
One of them you turn on.
In fact, you turn two of them on and you wait a minute.
Then you turn one of them off.
Then you walk in the room.
If the lightbulb is on, then it means the switch that you have left on is the--that switch goes to that bulb.
If it's off, then you go up and feel the lightbulb on the ceiling.
If it's warm, that means the lightbulb was on for a little while, and that means it connects to the switch that you had turned on and off.
If the lightbulb, though, is cold, that means it was never turned on and it has to be the third switch.
Will, what are your favorite kinds of puzzles?
I mean, I think we all have them--mathematical.
I happen to be a fan of anagrams.
Neal is not at all a fan of anagrams.
I can't stand the periodic table.
I mean, do you have favorites?
Well, I tell you, I have become addicted by sudoku since April.
And cryptic crosswords and the crosswords of the British style I love.
I love Friday- and Saturday-level New York Times crosswords that are, you know, just a real good, tough test of your puzzle-solving ability.
But really, you know, any kind of puzzle.
It's a jigsaw puzzle, you name it.
If it's a challenge, I'll do it.
Last Saturday's puzzle was a real bear, at least for me.

Did you hear the story about the guy who was filling out this, like, 3,000, 8,000-piece jigsaw puzzle and he was almost finally getting it and there was one piece missing, it turned out his dog ate it?
We got this from Ed Green(ph).
How many times during a day is the minute hand perpendicular to the hour hand?
